subject: Re: Pluggable Selector considered harmful? (Re: [junit] Re: Observations from a production use of JUnit4)
msgSnippet: ... C mon Cedric.  Have you really done serious Smalltalk coding?  I am not implying there weren t challenges, but this was *never* one of them.  The
messageBody:
On Feb 6, 2006, at 4:02 PM, Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> On 2/6/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
>>
>>
>>>> You can use Type Inference.
>>>
>>>
>>> Not when you don't have any types :-)
>>
>> True, but my mind was (silently?) focused on dynamic languages like
>> Smalltalk and Ruby.
>
>
> So is mine, and they're both plagued by this problem.

C'mon Cedric. Have you really done serious Smalltalk coding? I am
not implying there weren't challenges, but this was *never* one of
them. The image-based nature and all the tools for exploring it made
this a breeze.

>
> The only dynamically typed language that doesn't have this
> limitation is
> Groovy, which lets you specify types for your variables if you
> really want
> to (and most of the time, I really want to -- at least in method
> signatures,
> and then I let type inference do its magic).
>
> --
> Cédric
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>
>
>

>

Daryl

"Stress rarely has a positive impact on our ability to think.
Never, I'd guess."

-- Ron Jeffries, 2005
